Summary

D365 portals are a DfE service not a GOV.UK service, however GOV.UK patterns and frontend code can be used. To work with the D365 portal functionality and out-of-the-box limitations you'll sometimes need to use slightly different patterns and tweak the recommended frontend code. This site includes examples of best practice use for working with GOV.UK and DfE design patterns and frontend code on D365 portals.

The styles, patterns and components detailed on this site are based on the GOV.UK Design System and adapted for use with D365 portal services. There are additional styles, patterns and components on the GOV.UK Design System not included on this site. You can use these with D365 portal services without any D365 specific customisation* required e.g. HTML for tables.

Access the GOV.UK Design System (opens in a new tab)

* The additional styles, patterns and components referred to on the GOV.UK Design System are static HTML snippets which do not require adapting for use with the D365 WebApi service to submit data to the CRM database. The examples provided on the GOV.UK Design System contain sample data which you will need to replace with your own content.

Service standards

Your site or service must not:

  • identify itself as being part of GOV.UK
  • use the crown or GOV.UK logotype in the header
  • use the GDS Transport typeface
  • suggest that it's an official UK government website if it's not

These things are there to provide a consistent identity and navigation between GOV.UK and the sites and transactional services that hang off it. As D365 portal services are not on GOV.UK, there's no need to maintain that identity - in fact, you might confuse or mislead people if you do.

Appropriately styled page templates, header and footer are provided for your portal service on this site. See

All D365 portal services within DfE should be provided on the 'education.gov.uk' domain.
